Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about the elements of academic argumentation and different theories of privacy.
Writing, discussion, analysis of readings

Gives a historical overview of how privacy has been conceived and understood. Most of us this semester came in thinking it would be about technology privacy -- and it definitely touches in that. But be prepared to explore what privacy means sociologically, historically, politically as well.
Broad understanding of the current debate around privacy. Also a good start to academic writing.
I learned how to structure essays and give good arguments.

In this course, I learned valuable skills about critical thinking. I learned how to read academic articles, interpret others arguments, and construct my own arguments. I also learned a lot about writing in general, including advanced grammar, stylistic choices, and much more.

My writing and critical thinking skills developed immensely from this course as well as my ability to create strong arguments and assemble evidence that supported my thinking and persuaded the audience more.
I developed a stronger sense of writing with purposeful structure and primary/secondary source analysis.
I developed new perspectives in analyzing academic works and writing my own

By the end of the course, I learned how to write more logically and with better organization. I had my first experience writing a college level research paper, and it was time-consuming. I also had my first experiences breaking into college level writing in general. I learned that structure really was not more important than content and logical narrative, but I still feel like some types of structure were marked off for.
I learned how to think about and discuss mundane things from a more interesting perspective; the privacy perspective. Even from within privacy, there are many more perspectives to discuss from (such as economic, emotional, psychological.)
I learned how to come up with interesting and relevant questions on the fly by relating to things I'd already known about.
I improved my ability to logically dissect other people's arguments.

Strengths: Improved academic writing abilities, improved understanding of the elements that make an argument strong and weak. Increased ability to analyze and critique the arguments of others. I appreciated the analysis of works in pop culture (such as Black Mirror episodes). Weaknesses: Becomes boring after a while (very narrow topic), discussion not always very engaging.
Really good readings, discussion, and instruction - wished we had spent a little more time on contemporary matters of privacy instead of focusing mostly on old stuff

This could be interpreted as a strength or a weakness, but the course is very front loaded. The first half of the semester will feel like a mad dash of writing papers. An overwhelming positive is that the readings are often more engaging, like watching Black Mirror.
This class was about a very interesting subject and the projects were cool to do. The round table discussions sometimes had trouble getting participation and gaining momentum.

The main strength is the professor. Palmer was very engaging and helpful throughout the class and made the class much more enjoyable and valuable. An improvement would be to possibly debate and form arguments more in class to help when forming the main arguments for papers.

I think that the topic enabled the class to be inherently engaging.  Also, the class flowed very well throughout the year, as Palmer assigned appropriate readings that all tied into each other. I also really appreciated the feedback for each assignment.  Palmer went into great detail about each aspect of the papers, allowing me to really see the strengths and weaknesses so I could create a strong final draft.
I enjoyed the exposure to a wide variety of theorists and texts. I wish we spent a little more time on essay structure and the process of constructing an argument.

I didn't feel like I knew what I was doing for the first 2 papers. I didn't understand what was required, but I thought it was okay because I had a good understanding of the material and felt I could write competently on it. Not so. My first paper was really quite atrocious, because I didn't focus enough on a single theme and tried to write about all the things I thought were relevant. They may have been relevant, but they didn't help make my argument stronger. It would have been extremely helpful to see more examples of good writing in the format that was required, because much of what we were given to read were long academic drawls. Then, when I tried to learn from those academic drawls, my several page paper became an academic drawl, mediocrely condensed without adequate explanation. 
I received a rubric for the second and third papers, which helped immensely. However, I felt that the papers were different in format from the first paper, so I didn't have adequate preparation to figure out what my professor wanted. Honestly, I would've preferred more frequent writing assignments in the form of the final writing assignment (the judging panel one) because I felt like that would have allowed me to actually get practice before axing my paper grades. By the time the third paper came around, I thought I had everything figured out, but by then it was too late to significantly change my grade.
To be honest, I enjoyed everything besides writing the papers. I read a lot of interesting perspectives that I wouldn't have thought of otherwise, and discussed it with other intellectually curious folks. I feel like that's a big part of what I came to Yale to do. In the end, I felt like I learned a lot, but not a lot about writing. 
All we ever covered was writing in a narrow scope (academia) which I did not cover in high school. I believe I can talk competently about privacy theory and law because of all of our in-class discussions, and I feel like I have become a more interesting person for it, but I do not believe that this English 114 class served its purpose as a writing class. I feel like this was a writing class in which we rushed learning to write in order to write about the topics that were the real purpose of the class.
I would recommend this course to a student who needs a writing credit, wants to become a better writer, and/or has a serious interest in privacy, theory, and the law.
Yes definitely - I am a big fan of Palmer and he provided me with outstanding instruction that helped me improve my writing. I would absolutely take a course he teaches again.
Definitely a valuable experience to have as a first year. Teaches you how to make an academic argument, which you literally might not know how to do (even if you think you do) from high school.
Yes! Great subject matter with plenty of areas for open discussion and people all over differ in their opinions of the subject. Great framework for academic writing.
Yes. I would recommend this course to another student because the articles that we read were interesting and the topic is a contemporary issue.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It is an interesting topic, well structured, and a great professor.
Absolutely, a great class to develop as a writer and to discuss interesting and relevant topics.
Yes, for two reasons.  The topic itself is a very interesting idea to discuss in a seminar setting.  Also, the class has a very positive impact on one's writing as a whole.
Yes, because you come out of it a much better reader and writer.

Yes, I would recommend it. However, I would recommend it if you are interested in the subject material, not if you come from a poor writing background. I did the things that my professor recommended (going to a writing tutor, going to the writing center, going to office hours) but was still not up to par. The writing tutor and writing center would say that things were fine and good, but still not up to the standards of the professor. For this reason, I wanted to have more writing practice than the 3 major essays of the class. If you want to learn to write well, go somewhere else because that is not the focus of this class.
